7.text:
Well, good afternoon ladies and gentlemen.
Thank you very much for turning out in such

10.text:
cheering numbers on this rather sort of dreich
afternoon here in Chelsea.

17.text:
So I’m talking about Eric Kennington, and
particularly the work that he did during the

21.text:
Second World War, logically enough, considering
that we’re in the National Army Museum,

27.text:
It’s entitled ‘Portraits Like Bombs’
and this was a quote and the title was applied

34.text:
in September 1943 by an art critic to many
of the series of portraits of men that Kennington

41.text:
had drawn in the Home Guard, but who were
also Great War veterans.

47.text:
Now I’m just showing an image of the man himself, 
our hero for the hour, this is Eric Kennington

51.text:
aged about 30, drawn in 1918, so it gives you 
an idea of what the man looked like.

59.text:
But the epithet ‘Portraits Like Bombs’,
which I mention in my title, was applied by

66.text:
a contemporary critic in September 1943 to one of these 
home guardsmen who was also a Great War veteran.

72.text:
And this is the fearsome-looking ex-Gordon
Highlander, Sergeant Moir, of the 3rd Battalion,

79.text:
the Aberdeen Home Guard, which I am showing
on the screen at the moment.

82.text:
Moir was interpreted by many of the critics
reviewing this exhibition as ‘both thoroughly

87.text:
modern and yet also somehow timeless’, a
type oft-celebrated earlier on in the history

92.text: of art by artists such as Leonardo da Vinci.

95.text:
So if you look at Sergeant Moir from 1943
and then compare with the equally forbidding

102.text:
warrior...‘Portrait of a Warrior’ by Leonardo
da Vinci from about 1475.

107.text:
And critics in this...in responding to Kennington’s
exhibition at the Leicester Galleries in September 1943,

114.text:
where he showed this series of Home
Guard portraits, also compared portraits such

119.text:
as Moir favourably to works by that sort of
16th-century master of portraiture working

125.text:
at the court of Henry VIII, Hans Holbein the
Younger.

129.text:
This is his portrait of Sir John Godsalve
from 1532.

133.text:
Now, a little bit of information about the
man himself, a little bit of biographical detail.

139.text:
Kennington was born in Fulham into a sort of solidly 
professional and middle-class late-Victorian household.

145.text:
His father, Thomas Benjamin, was vice-president of the 
Royal Institute of Painters in Oils from 1906 to 1916.

154.text:
He was also a founder member of the New English
Art Club.

157.text:
Kennington was educated at St Paul’s School,
and the Lambeth School of Art, and just prior

163.text:
to the outbreak of the First World War he
was beginning to gain recognition for a series

168.text: of paintings and drawings depicting costermongers.

171.text:
And I’m showing you on the screen here,
this is his ‘The Costardmongers’ which

176.text:
was exhibited at the International Society
in April 1914, and it was one of the works

181.text:
that helped to bring him to public attention,
and the work itself was actually bought by

187.text:
the then very famous society portraitist William
Nicholson.

192.text:
Anyway, on 6 August 1914, Kennington volunteered
to serve as a private in the 13th Battalion,

200.text:
The London Regiment, Princess Louise’s Own
Kensingtons.

203.text:
I think mainly because the recruiting office
for this unit was just around the corner from

208.text:
Kennington’s studio, which was off Kensington
High Street.

212.text:
He undertook basic training near Abbots Langley
between August to November 1914, and then

219.text: he was sent...or went to France.

221.text:
He was in the front line in north-eastern
France until he was wounded in the left foot

228.text:
He...his middle toe on his left foot was amputated
and he almost lost the entire foot to infection.

236.text:
And recovering in hospital, first in London
and then in Liverpool, and then he was released

239.text:
from the Army with an honourable medical discharge
in June 1915.

244.text:
And then the rest of that year, of 1915, he
devoted to painting in oils and gold and silver

251.text:
paint in reverse on glass - a sort of icon-like,
jewel-like work, ‘The Kensingtons at Laventie, Winter 1914',

258.text:
which immortalised his comrades
in Number 7 Platoon, C Company of The Kensingtons.

266.text:
And you can just see this is Kennington, who
has included himself in...he’s in the top

278.text: So he’s amongst the members of his old platoon.

284.text:
Certainly you can say that Kennington knew what war 
at the sharp end in the trenches was like.

288.text:
He had seen men shot through the head by snipers,
riddled with machine-gun bullets as well as

293.text: blown to pieces by high explosive shells.

296.text:
In fact during the time he was with the battalion
in France, the Kensingtons suffered 127 causalities,

302.text:
about 20 per cent of the unit’s strength
when it had arrived in France in mid-November 1914.

309.text:
Now this work, ‘The Kensingtons at Laventie’,
touched on an episode after he’d...Kennington

317.text:
and his platoon had spent four days and nights in the 
firing line with the temperature at 20C below zero.

324.text:
The battalion had just made its way down a
mile of communication trenches, frozen mud

328.text:
up to their waists, sometimes up to four feet deep, 
to the relative safety of the much-shelled

333.text:
village of Laventie, which was still coming
under intermittent shellfire.

338.text:
And the scene that Kennington depicts in the
work, his platoon’s about to begin a five-mile

345.text:
march to reserve billets, which were out of
range of the German artillery.

350.text:
And in fact by the time that Kennington had
completed the painting towards the end of 1915,

354.text:
90 per cent of the 700-strong battalion
which he had arrived with in France early

361.text:
in November 1914, had become causalities - many
during the battles of Neuve-Chapelle in March 1915,

367.text: and particularly Aubers Ridge in May 1915.

374.text:
Now this...the painting, ‘The Kensingtons
at Laventie’, created a sensation when it

379.text:
was exhibited in a charity exhibition at the Goupil 
Gallery on Regent Street during April-July 1916.

387.text:
And Kennington was hailed by a number of leading
critics as ‘the painter who knew how to

391.text:
properly portray the stoically enduring British
Tommy’.

394.text:
For example, The Times declared: ‘He [Kennington] has 
painted the real war for us in all its squalor and glory.’

403.text:
And the following year, the celebrated portraitist
Sir John Lavery wrote in support of Kennington,

409.text:
as Kennington’s application to become an
official war artist working with the Department

414.text:
of Information, and I quote: ‘Mr Kennington,
in my opinion, has painted in “The Kensingtons”,

420.text:
the only picture of the Great War that I have
seen so far that will actually live.’

425.text:
So Kennington was appointed an official war
artist attached to the Department of Information

433.text:
in the spring of 1917, and he was sent off to France in 
August 1917, and he spent about seven months out in France.

443.text:
So after...and it’s interesting that additionally
he was only supposed to spend a month out

448.text:
in France in August 1917, but after the first
month had expired, he simply refused to come

455.text:
home and kept sending pleading letters to
his employers at the Department of Information

461.text:
asking that he be allowed to stay much longer
to, as he said, ‘learn the war’.

464.text:
And I’m just going to quickly show you a selection 
of the drawings that he produced between...

469.text:
these marvellous drawings, often drawn
in less than three-quarters of an hour in,

474.text:
or near, the front line during this period
of August 1917 to March 1918.

480.text:
So this is a Royal Engineer laying a field
telephone wire from September 1917.

490.text: In red chalk on a white background.

493.text:
A particular favourite of mine, a portrait of a  
19-year-old trench raider from the Lancashire Fusiliers

507.text:
The ‘Raider with a Cosh’ - a man from the 
3rd Battalion, the Rifle Brigade,

511.text:
that he drew preparing for a trench raid in February
1918, which is in the Tate Gallery’s collection.

519.text:
Also he didn’t just do portraits, he also did some 
quite sensitive drawings and also watercolours and pastels

525.text:
of the sort of camps in which resting soldiers were living, 
such as this rest camp from 1918.

533.text: He also did some drawings of some of the wounded.

541.text:
He had to be admitted to a casualty clearing
station himself suffering from trench fever

548.text:
- this was a malady caused by infected lice
bites.

553.text:
And so while he was recovering from a bout
of trench fever in a casualty clearing station,

558.text:
he drew a series of very sensitive drawings
of some of his fellow sufferers, some of the

564.text: other patients in the casualty clearing station.

567.text:
So this is a man who’s being treated for
the effects of mustard gas, which had been

571.text:
introduced for the first time on the Western
Front by the Germans in July 1917.

576.text:
And here’s another sufferer from mustard
gas effects drawn in 1918.

585.text:
So eventually Kennington was persuaded to
come back to England in March 1918, and in

592.text:
June-July 1918 a selection from the over 170
drawings in pastel and charcoal and watercolours

599.text:
were exhibited in an exhibition at the Leicester
Galleries, backed by the Ministry of Information.

605.text:
The exhibits were widely hailed as masterpieces,
and Kennington was identified as a portraitist

611.text:
to rival such great figures from the past
as Albrecht Dürer, Ingres, Holbein the Younger,

618.text:
as well as contemporaries such as Augustus
John, William Nicholson, William Orpen, and

627.text:
For example, in The New Statesmen, the poet
Laurence Binyon, an art critic, wrote of Kennington’s

631.text:
exhibits, and I quote: ‘Mr Kennington has
a genius for reality.

635.text:
He has not only the gift of exact and faithful
record, but the power of giving expression

641.text:
to the latent vehemence, energy and passion
that make up the controlled strength of a man.

646.text:
If a foreigner wished to see the British soldier, he could 
not do better than see him with Mr Kennington’s eyes.’

653.text:
Kennington, however, was not happy with the
Ministry of Information, and was still suffering

658.text:
from the lingering effects of trench fever,
and in effect he resigned from the Ministry

662.text: as a war artist in September 1918.

665.text:
However, two months later, in November 1918,
he signed up with the Canadian War Memorial Scheme

671.text:
which was the brainchild of Lord Beaverbrook
the newspaper magnate, and late in November 1918

676.text:
was sent out to France as a temporary first lieutenant 
attached to the Canadian Army

681.text:
and attached himself to the 16th Battalion Highlanders of Canada, 
part of the 3rd Infantry Brigade of the 1st Canadian Division.

691.text:
And while in France between November 1918 and March 1919, 
he made a series of over 40 studies of individual soldiers

697.text:
from the battalion who fought their last major battle 
of the war in October 1918.

704.text:
And then early in 1920 he painted a large
tribute in oils to the formidable-looking

709.text:
men of the much-decorated unit entitled ‘The
Conquerors’.

715.text:
And this was exhibited in Ottawa during the
summer of 1920, and then in October-November

720.text:
of the same year Kennington held a solo show
at the Alpine Club gallery in London.

724.text:
And on the basis of this painting, this oil ‘The Conquerors’, 
the art critic of The Sunday Times, Frank Rutter,

730.text:
wrote that ‘Kennington is...’, 
and I quote, ‘...one of our foremost portrait painters’.

736.text:
It’s interesting that one visitor to the
exhibition just before it closed was the celebrated

743.text:
leader of our irregular troops, TE Lawrence, who bought 
two of Kennington’s drawings of soldiers.

751.text:
Now Kennington may have thought that he was
finished with the British military, but Lawrence

755.text:
persuaded Kennington to come out to the Middle
East to draw personalities who appeared in

760.text:
his account of the war with the Ottoman Turks
that he was writing at the time, which was

764.text:
eventually published as ‘The Seven Pillars
of Wisdom’.

768.text:
And so Kennington was persuaded by Lawrence
to go out to the Middle East to draw some

773.text:
of the characters, or some of the personalities
who appeared in The Seven Pillars, including...

778.text:
this is a portrait he did of Lawrence from when he was 
in...he met Lawrence in Cairo in March 1921.

787.text:
Lawrence, in the end, wouldn’t allow this work to be 
reproduced in The Seven Pillars of Wisdom’s

793.text:
luxury subscribers edition, because he said that it was 
‘too obviously the spider in a web of its own spinning’.

801.text:
He thought it was just too revelatory of this, you know, 
incredibly enigmatic and rather sort of tricky personality.

811.text:
But somebody else that he drew at the time
was Field Marshal Allenby who was then the

818.text:
Commissioner...the High Commissioner for Egypt
in Cairo, and this was drawn in less than

826.text: an hour in March 1921 in the Semiramis Hotel.

829.text:
And just to show you how Kennington could
catch a likeness, this is him, a photograph

834.text:
of him taken the year before, and then this
is the man himself drawn by Kennington.

846.text:
Kennington remained friendly with Lawrence until 
Lawrence was killed in his tragic accident in May 1935.

853.text:
Now for the next sort of four years, Kennington
devoted himself to carving a remarkable tribute

859.text:
in stone to his friend, a recumbent Lawrence
in the guise of an Arab sheikh wearing Arab dress

869.text:
in the form of a recumbent tomb effigy
which is now in the small Anglo Saxon church

876.text: of St Martin’s, Wareham in Dorset.

878.text:
So this is sort of showing you an image here
of the head of the tomb effigy that Kennington carved,

886.text:
and more-or-less was just finishing, putting the 
finishing touches to, as the Second World War broke out.

893.text:
But he also did some other military figures
just before the war broke out, as he kept

898.text:
contacts with the military thanks to Lawrence’s continuing 
connections with the RAF and also with the Tank Corps.

909.text:
And this is Kennington’s portrait of ‘the father of the 
tank’, and the Oxford military historian,

913.text:
Major General Sir Ernest Swinton
that was drawn in 1938.

918.text:
The sitter was amused that Kennington had made him look 
like, and I quote, ‘Attila the Hun, the wrath of God’.

925.text:
But he was amused - he rather liked being portrayed 
in such a formidable light did Sir Ernest.

931.text: So this is at the Tank Museum in Bovington.

934.text:
Now, late in November 1939, the War Artists
Advisory Committee was created as part of

942.text:
the Ministry of Information, chaired by the then director 
of the National Gallery, Sir Kenneth Clark.

948.text:
And one of the first of the 30 artists or
so that Clark considered for employment was

953.text:
Kennington, specifically as identified as
the portraitist...or likely to be an excellent

959.text:
portraitist of, and I quote, ‘the fighting
man’.

962.text:
So Kennington was appointed as an official
war artist in December 1939, with a remit

968.text:
to, or a brief, to draw in pastel or charcoal,
portraits at 25 guineas a time.

974.text:
And the artist estimated that he would need
at least three hours per sitter.

979.text:
And Kennington promptly asked to draw the
fearsome chief of the Imperial General Staff,

984.text:
the 6-foot-4-tall general Sir Edmund Ironside,
which he did in January 1940.

990.text:
And I’m showing you an image... this is
Ironside drawn by Kennington in Cairo in 1921,

997.text:
and then he drew him again in January 1940
as an official war artist.

1007.text:
Now I think Kennington was soon having trouble
with the War Artists Advisory Committee as

1011.text:
he did not get on with the War Office representative
on the committee - a newspaper man called Colin Coote.

1018.text:
The War Office gave him the distinct impression,
according to Kennington, that it was not interested in,

1025.text:
Kennington was supposed to go to France to draw the 
commander of the British Expeditionary Force,

1029.text:
Lord Gort, but the trip was repeatedly
postponed.

1032.text:
And it was only after sort of constantly nagging
at the War Office representative on the

1039.text:
War Artists Advisory Committee, Coote, that Kennington
was...that a series of other portrait sittings

1046.text:
were set up with other personalities within
the War Office.

1049.text:
And in March 1940, he drew this marvellous
portrait of Major General RH Dewing who was

1055.text:
the Director of Military Operations, in again
less than three hours.

1060.text:
I love the fact that his moustache looks as
though it’s about to leap off and tackle

1067.text:
But it’s a bit of a leitmotif in that Dewing
was somebody who had been a rising star in

1074.text:
the British Army at the time towards the end
of the First World War, but the war had ended

1080.text:
really before he could actually get his hands
on a sort of suitably senior position, and

1086.text:
so he was just a little bit too old when the
Second World War broke out and had to retire

1090.text: about 18 months after this portrait was drawn.

1094.text:
So I think Kennington always, as a Great War
veteran himself, felt a lot of sympathy for

1099.text:
those who were in that sort of position, who
hadn’t quite made it to the top at the end

1103.text:
of the First World War, and therefore were
just deemed to be a little too old to shine

1108.text:
in the Second World War in a sort of high
capacity.

1112.text:
So Kennington eventually persuaded the Admiralty
to send him off to Plymouth where he drew

1118.text:
a series of portraits of sailors who distinguished
themselves, first of all in the Battle of the River Plate

1122.text:
in December 1939, such as this marvellous portrait 
here of Senior Stoker Andrew Martin of HMS Exeter,

1131.text:
But he also drew portraits of heroes of the
twin naval victories of Narvik in April 1940,

1138.text:
such as Petty Officer Barnes of HMS Eclipse
with this sort of lovely evocation of a

1149.text:
So he was still sort of a little in bad odour
with the War Artists Advisory Committee for

1155.text:
being one of the artists who proved to be
the sort of most troublesome, or, you know,

1159.text:
members of the awkward squad, because Kennington
was always asking to be sent to...be given

1164.text: more sitters than he was being allotted.

1167.text:
So actually Kennington jumped before he could
be pushed, and actually when, with the creation

1173.text:
of the Home Guard, the Local Defence Volunteers,
in mid-May 1940, he jumped at the chance to

1178.text:
join that, and he left the War Artists Advisory
Committee as an official war artist in mid-May 1940.

1188.text:
And he resigned, convinced he was doing far
more for the war effort by joining the Home Guard,

1195.text:
and by early July 1940 he was in charge
of a section of six countrymen in the

1201.text:
south Oxfordshire countryside, defending an observation
post he’d set up to the north of his home in Ipsden.

1207.text:
And at the time, in letters that he wrote
to his older brother William, it’s clear

1210.text:
that Kennington did not at all romanticise
the Home Guard, or over idealise its personnel.

1216.text:
Their equipment was pitiful, weapons were
non-existent, senior officers displayed little

1221.text:
drive and initiative and impotently buried
themselves in red tape and paperwork.

1227.text:
And he noted to his older brother: ‘The
men, if not suitably motivated, did not report

1232.text:
for duty in the evenings, but sloped off after
roll call to go poaching, fishing, or playing

1240.text:
So just keep that in mind when you look at
some of these amazing portraits that he later

1244.text:
drew of home guardsmen, and that he actually
did know the reality of...he wasn’t sort of

1251.text:
So, as I said, Kennington had left the War
Artists Advisory Committee as a war artist

1257.text:
in mid-May 1940, but it quickly became clear
when the War Artists Advisory Committee held

1264.text:
an exhibition of official war art that it had commissioned 
at the National Gallery in July 1940,

1269.text:
that Kennington was by far the most popular artist on display, 
and he was the star portraitist.

1276.text:
His portraits of generals and sailors were
singled out for particular praise, and certainly

1280.text:
after defeat in France in May-June 1940, the
country needed urgent reassurance that it

1286.text:
actually still had the men who could, and
I quote, ‘win the war’.

1290.text:
Art critic H Granville-Fell expressed a sentiment
felt by many visitors, and I quote:

1298.text:
I’m just showing you a few images looking suitably 
debonair in his Home Guard uniform from 1940.

1311.text: But just go back to Stoker Martin.

1317.text:
Talking about this particular work, H Granville-Fell
wrote: ‘Kennington’s harsh iron technique

1322.text:
has a force admirably suited to conveying
unflinching and dauntless resolution in the

1326.text: faces of his seamen and soldiers.

1328.text:
I know of no other artist who can so convincingly
depict the salt of the earth, and evoke palpably,

1335.text:
in a portrait, the very essence and savour
of courage.’

1339.text:
So the War Artists Advisory Committee in August
1940 rather had to eat a little humble pie,

1346.text:
asking Kennington if he would return to work
for it to draw portraits this time of RAF personnel.

1352.text:
And the committee’s secretary, who rejoiced
in the marvellous sobriquet of E Montgomery

1357.text:
O’Rourke Dickey - there’s a name to conjure
with - wrote to Sir Kenneth Clark that month,

1364.text:
and I quote: ‘The best of this artist’s
portraits [ie Kennington] of sailors in the

1369.text:
exhibition at the National Gallery have, in
the eyes of the public, a nobility not shared

1374.text:
by any other work that’s on display at the
National Gallery.

1378.text:
These portraits typify the fighting man who’s
going to win the war for us.’

1384.text:
So Kennington started working for the War
Artists Advisory Committee again as an official

1388.text:
war artist in September 1940 as the Battle
of Britain was reaching a crescendo, and by

1394.text:
the end of the year he’d completed over a dozen 
portraits of Battle of Britain fighter aces,

1398.text:
such as this lovely portrait of Flight
Lieutenant Albert Gerald ‘Zulu’ Lewis,

1407.text:
who was a South African, drawn in October 1940, 
and also Pilot Officer James ‘Ginger’ Lacey

1414.text:
who, not surprisingly from his sobriquet,
had red hair, drawn again in October 1940.

1422.text:
So Kennington worked as an official artist
attached to the RAF throughout 1940-41.

1428.text:
But typically with Kennington it meant, being
a member of the God’s awkward squad, he

1432.text:
was soon falling out with the Royal Air Force
representative on the War Artists Advisory Committee,

1437.text: a man called Air Commodore Harald Peake.

1441.text:
And twice in May 1941 Kennington threatened
to resign because Peake wanted him to draw

1446.text:
too many, as he put it, ‘knobs’...too
many senior officers.

1450.text:
But he was talked out of this action by no
less than Air Marshal Sir Charles Portal,

1454.text:
chief of the Air Staff, who you'd think probably
had more other things to do in the middle

1459.text: of 1941 than to talk him out of resigning.

1462.text:
However, so Kennington stayed with the RAF
as a war artist, and meanwhile, at the same

1469.text:
time, works by him were still being exhibited
at the National Gallery, but some criticism

1473.text:
of the work was beginning to creep into the
press.

1475.text:
For example, Eric Newton, who was the art
critic of The Sunday Times, wrote, and I quote:

1479.text:
‘Eric Kennington goes on and on with his
over-life-size portraits of supermen.

1483.text:
They are strident things whose assertiveness
almost hurts the eyes.’

1488.text:
But then he did concede: ‘They do look like men 
who are going to win the war.

1493.text:
Dropped as leaflets over enemy country,
I can imagine them being as effective as a bomb.’

1502.text:
Now Kennington had a habit of accepting commissions,
or just generally drawing portraits of people

1507.text:
he admired, when Air Commodore Peake, the
RAF representative, thought he should really

1513.text: be focusing entirely on men of the RAF.

1515.text:
So for example in September 1941, Kennington
drew a compelling portrait of an exhausted

1522.text:
Field Marshal Sir Archibald Percival Wavell,
to whom Kennington had been first introduced

1527.text:
initially in the early 1920s by none other
than TE Lawrence.

1531.text:
Now Kennington drew Wavell in September 1941
when he was briefly passing through London

1536.text:
before assuming command of the British forces
in the Far East.

1540.text:
Wavell had inflicted a spectacular defeat on the 
Italians in Libya in late 1940 - early 1941,

1548.text:
before in turn suffering a drubbing
at the hands of Rommel in the spring of 1941,

1555.text:
culminating in the failure of the Battleaxe
offensive of June 1941 which Wavell had launched,

1561.text:
against his better judgment, at the urging
of Prime Minister Churchill.

1564.text:
And I think it’s interesting that in this
portrait, Kennington does not try to disguise

1569.text:
the fact that Wavell had lost an eye on the
Western Front in the First World War, and

1573.text:
the field marshal was rather self-conscious
concerning this disfigurement.

1578.text:
A man of few, if no words, famously taciturn,
according to his son Wavell could relax with

1584.text:
Kennington because he was an old friend of
their mutual friend Lawrence.

1588.text:
Wavell thought that this portrait was all
too revealing of his state of mind in the

1594.text:
wake of the Battleaxe fiasco and his abrupt
removal from command of the British forces

1598.text:
in the Middle East, having lost the confidence
of a certainly more eloquent and more voluble Churchill.

1606.text:
So two months after drawing Wavell, Kennington secured 
two months’ leave from the War Artists Advisory Committee

1612.text:
to visit the 11th Armoured Division, 
which was based near Ripon in North Yorkshire.
